Legal_Issue: Can the Ontario Foundation independently claim 'March of Dimes' as an official mark under s. 9(1)(n)(iii) of the Trade-marks Act?
Evidence_Assessment: Registrar issued notices without evidence of independent adoption by the Ontario Foundation
Burden_of_Proof: On the Ontario Foundation to demonstrate independent adoption and use
Legal_Rule: Under s. 9(1)(n)(iii), only public authorities that have adopted and used a mark can claim it as an official mark. A licensee's use does not constitute independent adoption.
Procedural_Issue: Lack of evidence supporting independent adoption by the Ontario Foundation
Grounds_for_Claim: Ontario Foundation used 'March of Dimes' under a licensing agreement, not independently
Outcome_on_Merits: Ontario Foundation cannot independently claim the marks due to its licensed status
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Registrar failed to require evidence of independent adoption
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of licensing agreement between National Council and Ontario Foundation
Legal_Framework: Official marks regime under Trade-marks Act
Applicant_Challenge: National Council challenged the Registrar's issuance of official mark notices
Claimant_Status: National Council as trademark owner and licensor
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Ontario Foundation lacked standing as independent public authority adopter
Outcome_of_Review: In favor of the National Council
Governing_Rule: Only public authorities that independently adopt and use a mark may register it as an official mark
